body:

@ptgoetz I ran into the same problem on another machine. 

> git clone git://github.com/apache/incubator-storm.git incubator-storm-mvn
> curl https://github.com/apache/incubator-storm/pull/14.patch > 14.patch
> cd incubator-storm-mvn/
> git apply --check ../14.patch
> git apply ../14.patch
> mvn install

@anfeng @xumingming 
Thanks for taking a look at this, I appreciate it.

It looks like the dependency on the shaded libthrift jar is the issue.

I'll take a deeper look, and fire up some VMs to test in a clean environment.

Out of curiosity, if you run the following, what happens (from the source root):

```
cd storm-deps/libthrift
mvm clean install
cd ../../
mvm clean install
```

Thanks again,

Taylor

dagit:

Might be related: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STORM-143

revans2:

P. Taylor Goetz We at Yahoo have done a lot of work on securing storm and are currently running with it in production. This includes some work towards this JIRA. We have our own single sign on that we support through an http filter. I have been looking for a good way for us to get back in sync with the community, if this is a high priority for you, I would be happy to take some of my weekend and upmerge all that we have done to the latest apache. My biggest concern is that it is a lot of code. I am fine if you want to try and review it all in one monster session, but I think I would prefer it if we could file a rollup JIRA for security and we can pull our changes onto a branch, and then file smaller JIRA to pull back different parts of it to master as they are reviewed. That way people can see and start using security now, but with the stipulation that things might change.

@ptgoetz I continue to see those 3 errors. mvn log indicates various topology configuration issues:

...................

0 when number of tasks is greater than 0)>

he following: #{"." "/" ":" "\\"})>

...................

a.lang.Number')>

msg:Each element of the list topology.kryo.register must be a java.lang.String.)>

Try removing your ~/.storm/storm.yaml

I have seen this mess things up in the past

—Bobby

Okay, I as able to reproduce the the issue that @anfeng is seeing. The difference is that I was running my branch in isolation and @anfeng was overlaying this branch with what's currently in master.

The difference is that master now has @d2r's pull request #11 merged (not placing blame -- just observing :) ).

I will investigate, but I suspect one of the unit tests is using a test config that doesn't pass validation.

Why this only shows up under maven and not leiningen is what I don't understand (and what scares me).

This has nothing to do with maven or this pull request. The master branch is broken.

```
git checkout master
lein sub clean
lein sub install
cd storm-core
lein test
```

_snip_

```
Ran 150 tests containing 101433 assertions.
0 failures, 3 errors.
```

tdunning:

This isn't just an inconvenient limitation. This is also potentially a rather serious security bug in that lack of escaping implies that it is likely that it is possible to inject arbitrary commands using things like back ticks.

dagit:

In this case we are going to the os without using a shell. The program to be run is hard-coded to 'java' (both before and after the patch). An attack using backticks as part of the topology name would result in the backticks being passed literally as part of the argument to java.

It would be possible to use the topology name to pass additional options to java. We already facilitate this through topology.worker.childopts.

Non-options would be treated as arguments, and additional arguments would cause the worker to exit immediately (wrong number of arguments).

panfeng412:

A simple pool of DRPCClient instances.

Each DRPCClientPool acts as a pool for all clients. To use, instantiate an DRPCClientPool and use

{@link #getClient()}

to get a DRPCClient from the pool.

Once you are done with it, close your instance of

{@link DRPCClientIface} by calling {@link DRPCClientIface#close()}.

DRPCClientPool can be construct with the following parameters:
drpcServers: which specifies the DRPC server list, with format "host1:port1,host2:port2,host3:port3". The pool will load-balances different DRPC servers with Round-Robin policy.

maxSize: which defines the most DRPCClient references that will ever be retained for each DRPC server. Default is {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}.
clientFactory: which defines factory to create new {@link DRPCClientIface}

. Default is

{@link DRPCClientFactory}

.

panfeng412:

How to use it:
1) First create a DRPCClientPool:
final String drpcServers = "host1:port1,host2:port2,host3:port3";
final int maxSize = 10;
DRPCClientPool pool = new DRPCClientPool(drpcServers, maxSize);

2) Get DRPCClientIface (the interface of DRPCClient), make rpc call, and put it back:
DRPCClientIface client = pool.getClient();
// Make drpc calls to DRPC server (eg. ReachTopology in storm-starter)
try {
String result = client.execute("reach", "foo.com/blog/1");
} catch (DRPCExecutionException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
} catch (TException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
} finally {
//Put client back to the pool
client.close();
}
......

3) At last, close the pool:
try {
pool.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}

xiaokang:

hi Aaron Zimmerman , I've submitted a pull request on the old storm git repo https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/pull/741.

The core code modification is about 300 lines and many others are generated by thrift. We have deployed this feature on production clusters about 6 months. Any advice is welcome!

main points:

1. interface changes (compatible with old versions)
1.1 zk add :topology-version and :update-duration-sec fields to StormBase:status map
1.2 zk add :topology-version to executor heartbeat
1.3 worker local state add versions dir to storm worker's current running topology-version
1.4 nimbus add updateTopology interface
1.5 add topology-version field to storm.thrift three struct: TopologySummary ExecutorSummary TopologyInfo

2. topology update process
2.1 storm client run "storm jar xxxx -c topology.update=true" to invoke topology update process
2.2 storm client upload new jar file to nimbus
2.3 storm client call nimbus updateTopology interface
2.4 nimbus check the new topology and replace stormdist/storm-id dir
2.5 nimbus update StormBase in zk, set :topology-version(for destination version) and :update-duration-sec(for all workers update process duration) fields to StormBase:status map
2.6 supervisors check zk StormBase and do the update work if topology's local version is not the same with zk version
2.6.1 sync-supervisor download the latest code from nimbus to local stormdist/topology-version dir
2.6.2 each supervisor schedule the topology's worker update at a rand(expect-max-update-time) time point
2.6.3 sync-process check local worker version, if it is not the same with sync-supervisor downloaded version and update time point reached, set worker state to a new :update state
2.6.4 sync-process kill workers in :update state as normally
2.6.5 sync-process restart killed worker as normally, expect that read topology and conf from stormdist/topology-version dir
2.6.6 new worker heartbeat to zk with new topology-version, it can be displayed on web ui to check update progress

On same subject, we should also add "/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu" directory into library path.

Reasoning :
/usr/lib64 is standard for Red Hat world whereas /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu is used in Debian multi-arch distribution (see https://wiki.ubuntu.com/MultiarchSpec and https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch)

This patch will fail if the arg happens to have any spaces in it.

-Djava.tmpio.dir=/mnt/foo\ bar/

Instead of splitting on spaces, pass the jvmopts as a list to begin with.

I put a pull request in for a different implementation of this fix, before being aware of it: https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/pull/783

Actually, seems your fix will fail in case if in STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS  will be few options.
STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS="-Da1=1 -Da2=2 -Da3=3"
in your case will produce again single record:
a1="1 -Da2=2 -Da3=3"

The way you specify ENV opts implies to escape all spaces, so you just can't hope that in one case your space will separate values, while in other it'll be treated as path part.

My fix is valid for zero, one, two or more STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS values, while your only valid for zero, or one (but it respect space).

I'll poke some local tests though for space cases.

Ah, good point! I missed that. In my testing, I did pass in two args in the STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS, but I wasn't checking that Java was actually seeing them as independent variables. That explains a thing or two!

shlex.split should probably be used instead of split in your patch.

Seems right fix will be something like this:

jvmopts=["-Dstorm.jar=" + jarfile] + [j.replace("STORM_SPACE_MAGIC","\ ") for j in JAR_JVM_OPTS.replace("\ ","STORM_SPACE_MAGIC").split(" ") if j])

Could we do shlex.split when we grab the env var?
https://github.com/jpotter/storm/blob/moved-to-apache/bin/storm#L48

Your solution would fail on this:
export STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS="-Dcom.example.key1=hello\ -Dcom.example.key2=there\"

For that string, key1 should parse to "hello\" and key2 should parse to "there\". Your split on "\ " would generate a single key, key1, with value "hello\ -Dcom.example.key2=there\".

Python's shlex library already does all of the shell escape parsing -- it can get pretty complicated.

import shlex
...
jvmopts=["-Dstorm.jar=" + jarfile]
if JAR_JVM_OPTS: jvmopts += shlex.split(JAR_JVM_OPTS)

(Note that shlex.split tries to read from STDIN if the arg given to it is Null.)

d2r: Yes, that would probably be cleaner! Plus avoid the Null check, since at that point, it's guaranteed that the return from os.getenv will be a string.

import shlex
...
JAR_JVM_OPTS = shlex.split(os.getenv('STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS', ''))
I'm a little behind on this – what does the maven shade plugin do exactly? It renames packages?

Yes, it will rename packages at the bytecode level. So in the storm source code we can use "org.apache.thrift". But at the time of packaging the jar, "org.apache.thrift" will be renamed to "org.apache.thrift7", and thus avoid conflicts with user code that pulls in a different version of thrift.

The maven shade plugin doesn't know anything about clojure source (it seems to be fine with clojure AOT byte code), so it won't relocate packages. The transformer in this pull request looks for clojure source files (".clj"), and does the same package transformation on clojure code, that the shade plugin does in bytecode -- basically just a regex replace.

Documentation Note: one thing I've noticed in testing this in multiple environments is that the build should be run on a machine with no less than 1GB RAM. Otherwise you can get random failures that I imagine are swallowed OOMEs and the Linux OOME killer.

At runtime, the build produced seems happy with a 750MB RAM vm, at least with simple topologies like word count.
What happens when the underlying library uses reflection? I assume this can't handle this case...?
My understanding/experience: if the reflection is in bytecode it will be fine. If the reflection is in non-AOT clojure, then the transformer will rewrite the code appropriately.

To see the result of the transform, do an `mvm install` in `storm-core` and then expand the resulting jar in `target`. In the clojure sources you should see that all references to `org.apache.thrift` have been changed to `org.apache.thrift7`. You should also see that that package transform has been applied to compiled class files as well.

revans2:

The issue is that command line arguments are always written as strings. Not numbers, not lists, not maps. I remember a pull request or issue on github to try and fix this, but I cannot find it now. Essentially in the code that parsed the command line options it looked to see if the value looked like a number, and if it did, it converted it to a number and stored it in the config. There was also some code for lists and things too.
